table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: Japanese Secrecy
div.p: Nothing has been more remarkable in the present war than the extraordinary secrecy maintained by the Japanese Naval and Military General Staffs. The losses of the Japanese fleet are absolutley uncertain ; no one can tell us, for example, whether the "Hatsuse" is the only Japanese battleship that has succumbed to the Russian mines, and what was the vessel that left the Japanese line during the battle of August 10, 1904. There is a vague impression that two Japanese ironclads have gone down ; four only took part in the great sea fight off Port Arthur, while nothing whatever is known of the losses of the larger cruisers. The "Daily Telegraph" stated some time back that the "Takasago" had perished on the same day that the "Sai Yen" ran on a mine, and what loss the Japanese torpedo flotillas have sustained is very variously estimated.

In most cases the Mikado's Government has neither affirmed nor denied the loss of ships reported almost weekly during the blockade of Port Arthur, and silence has proved golden in that the Russian succours wandering aimlessly off the East African Coast have not the slight-est notion of the strength of Admiral Togo's fleet. They may have to face five battleships, they may have to face three. The strength of the Japanese destroyer and submarine flotillas is equally unknown. Now and again stories come of fleets 20 strong seen cruising 100 miles E. of Hongkong or of a host of torpedo craft patrolling Formosan waters, but nothing definite and precise.

And if the Japanese secrecy in regard to their naval operations has been successful it has been more successful on land, where, what with Chinamen and correspondents, the chnces of leakage of important news are infinitely greater. But Japan has succeeded up to the great fight at Mukden in keeping concealed the whereabouts of some of her principal units. At Liao-Yang the Guard, 2nd and 12th divi-sions under Kuroki, the 5th and 10th under Nodzu, and the 3rd, 4th and 6th under Oku, with several reserve brigades, formed the Ja-panese army. The 1st was known to have been left at Port Arthur ; where were the rest? In the autumn it became known that the 9th and 11th were at Port Arthur, and early in 1905 it transpired that the 8th had played a promi-nent part at Heikontai. Then there was the 7th; it was only a few days ago that the "Times" correspondent informed the world that this force, destined to conquer Saghalien (said some) or hold Korea, according to others, had actually arrived in November in time to storm the 203-Metre Hill. As for the indepen-dent reserve brigades, no one seems sure of their exact position, nor of the nature of the army of occupation in Korea

And then in the height of the battle of Mukden three territorial divisions under General Kawamura, who, as all the world believed, was landing in N. Korea and pre=paring to assail Vladivostock, appear on General Linievitch and for all the Russian leaders. For this successful calculated secrecy means that you have a whole people before you that is not only patriotic - most people can feel and talk for their country - but has the power of understanding what the pro-secution of a successful war demands. Other nations have scarificed lives in war with the same iron patriotism, others have trained their hearts and wills to accept war, not as a horror and an abomination, nor as a field for theatricals, but as a necessary if highly disagreeable incident in international relations; but none have sacrificed their comfort so far as to refrain from writing or talking copious-ly in war-time, to the great comfort of them-selves and their enemy's Intelligence Depart-ment.

div.head:
Battle of Tieling
Severe fighting
Guns abandoned
No further stand till harbin

div.p: TOKIO, lnarcn ii.
At Tieling the Russians set fire to the pro­visions and fodder, which were piled round the station, two-thirds being destroyed. N umerous spoils were captured. *
A great number of prisoners were captured by the Japanese right wing. (Reuter.)
The newspapers' despatches estimate the casualties at the battle of Tieling at 19,000. KsAipatkin was obliged to abandon his stores and 80 guns. (Reuter.")

Reuter's correspondent with General Oku says that Tieling was occupied after a severe fight, the Russians retiring in confusion. It is not believed that the Russians will make an­other stand south of Harbin. The Japanese covered almost 90 miles in a fortnight, fighting practically every inch of the way. (Reuter.)

div.head:
GENERAL KUROPATKIN.
HIS RETURN TO RUSSIA.

div.p: St. Petersburg, March IT.
General Kuropatkin has been relieved of his command and replaced by General Linievitch.
(Havas, i
It is reported that Kuropatkin is already en route for St. Petersburg. (Reuter.)

GERMANY AND JAPAN.
PROBABLE FLOTATION OF LOAN.

div.p: Count von Bulow, speaking in the Reichstag, said there was absolutely no reason why Ger­many should endeavour to prevent the placing of the Russian loan in Germany. She would equally put no difficulties in the way of Japan . in a simjiar contingency.
It ig reported that this declaration is in connection with the news that Japan is about tD float a loan in Germany. (Reuter.

div.head: The Plaque.—
div.p: The only case of plague existing in Egypt was discharged as cured yesterday.

div.head: Jewish Pilgrimage. —
div.p: The S.S. "Thalia," with the members of the Jewish pilgrimage on board, left Alexandria yesterday afternoon for Jatfa. .

div.head: German Sportverein.—
div.p: The Alexandrian members of the German Sporting Club will give their annual entertainment on Saturday next, 25th inst., at the Eden Theatre.

div.head: The Abyssinian Bank.—
div.p: The concession granted to the National Bank of Egypt by the Emperor Menelik for the establishment of a State bank in Abyssinia is for fifty years.

The "Mahroussa."—It is stated that the Finance Ministry has provided for the expen­diture of L.E. 7,900 on the Khedive's S.Y. "Mahroussa" and the purchase of a steam launch for his Highness's servioe.

div.head: Suicide.—
div.p: A French lady, residing in the Moharrem Bey quarter of Alexandria, com­mitted suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting herself with a revolver. She left a letter stating that her aotion was inspired by family reasons.

div.head: Lake Menzaleh. —
div.p: The contract for the drainage of Lake Menzaleh over an area 20 kilometres long and 2 kilometres wide, has been given to Messrs. Sylvas Frties, at the price oC 750,000 Ire. The work is to be begun at once.

div.head: Anglo-American Co.—
div.p: The Anglo American Nile Navigation and Hotel Company is con­templating some changes owing to the partial severance of Mr. Thubron's connection with this successful company, particularly in regard to the management of its Boulac engineering aud arsenal works..

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.—
div.p: Variety and ballet continue to be the attractions at this theatre. Masked balls will be given to-night and to­morrow night A matinee performance takes place to-morrow. The first performance of the "revue" Alexandria en Baisse is announced for Tuesday next

div.head: Alexandria Arcrsological Society.—
div.p: The new Bulletin of the society has just been published, and its editor, Professor Breccia, is to be congratulated on the interesting charac ter of its contents. These include an account of Hermupohs Magna by the editor, an article by Mr. C. C. Edgar on a terra cotta representa­tion of the screw of Archimedes, some disser­tations On the treasures of the Alexandria Museum by Mr. Dutilh, and a notice of the recent finds and excavations in Alexandria by the editor.

div.head: Music at the Hotels. —
div.p: The Tsigane or­chestra, which has met with so much success at Cairo during the season, left to-day for Europe by the Austrian Lloyd steamer. The management of Shepheanl's Hotel and Ghezi- reh Palace have, however, engaged another band, the members of which have been seleoted from among the best soloists of the Khedivial Opera House orchestra The programme ol performances is as follows : every aiternoon, from 4 to 6, on Ghezireh Palace terrace; at uighr, during and alter diuuer, in both hotels alternatively. The small dances in both hotels will be kept on up till the middle of April.

div.head: Industrial School for the Blind. —
div.p: The bazaar in aid of the Industrial School for the Blind, which was held on Tuesday last, realised the very creditable sumofP.T. 20,709. Thanks are accorded to all who gave their help in attaining this very satisfactory result. Where all did so well, and gave their services so voluntarily, it would be invidious to mention names; but the work of the Misses Alexandra and Julia Sinudino, daughters of Mr. M. Sinadino, calls for special mention, inasmuch as these two young ladies were instrumental in raising £101 for the bazaar. Thanks are also tendered to Brig.-Geueral Bullock, C.B., for the use of a tent; to CoL McCracken and the officers of the Berks Regiment for the regi­mental band, and to Mrs. Anastas and her pupils for the exceedingly clever presentation of the play "Beauty and the Beast."

div.head: PERSONAL AND Social
div.p: The ex-Empresa Eugenie and suite arrived at Cairo yesterday afternoon on their return Irom their trip up the Mile. The ex-Emprees drove at once to the Savoy Hotel, where the usual suite of rooms had been reserved for the distinguished party. The ex-Empresa and suite dined in the Savoy Restaurant in the evening.
Sir Ernest Cassel's party at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening included the Duke and Duohess of Devonshire, Mr. Vinoent Corbet, Birch Pasha, Sir William Garstin, Mrs. CasBel, and Mr. Castelli.
Mr. William Waldorf Astor also entertained a party at dinner at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening.

Mr. Hoare having retired from the firm of chartered accountants, Hoare and Russell, the latter has taken Mr. Kerr, C.A., into partner­ship. A formal notice to this effect appears on pago 6 of to-day'I issue,

div.head: The Russian Squadron
div.p: sighted near damietta
(From our Correspondent).

Port Said, Friday night The Me8sageries Maritimes "Senegal," which entered our port this morning, reports thatlast night she sighted four men-of-war, which she took to be Russians, about 60 miles from Damietta. It was a very dark night and the vessels could not be distinctly discerned, but as no other men-of war are known to be bound this way it is concluded that they are Russians. They should reach here at dawn to-morrow morning.

div.head: MUTINY AMONG RUSSIAN TROOPS.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Port Said, Friday.

I bear on fcery good authority that the Rus­sians soldiers, wfio arrived here the other day bv the "Himalaya" were in a continual state of mutiny, and that towards the end of the voyage matters became so serious that the crew of the ship had to.keep their watch with revolvers in their hands. I am also told that when they arrived at Suez and heard of the loss of 20,000 men at Mukden they made it an occasion for a final carousal and drank every drop of wine there was in the ship.

div.head: Notes from Suakin
div.p: The Sirdar's Visit
SuakiD, March 8.

His Highness's Coast Guard cruiser "Abd- jl-Mouneim" arrived here from Suez on the tth inst to await the arrival of H.E. the Sirdar, Sir F. R. Wingate Pasha, in order to sonvey him to Suez about the 10th inst

Miralai Macauley Bey, R.E., Director of the Sudan Railways, acoompanied by Kaimakam Saduler Bey, Director of Sudan Customs, and Yousbashi Hassanein Effendi Rifaat, Staff Offi­cer, Sudan Railways, left here by special train on the 5th inst for Railhead, near Korn 0b6ana, to meet the Sirdar and his staff.

The Sirdar passed the night of the 6th inst. 7 miles from Railhead. The following morning his Excellency visited Kom-Ob3ana, where the famous rock-cutting took place under the Hon. Anthony Pelham, and reached Railhead at 9.30 a.m. There his Excellency entered the special train for 4|pakin, which he reached at 12.r5 p.m. The Sirdar's train stopped at Shaata Gate station, where a special railway platform had been made for him. His arrival at the station was announced by a salute of 19 guns, and a guard of honor, furnished by the 3rd Battalion Egyptian Army, was present at the Btation. *

After having shaken hands with several of the officials and sheikhs of tribes, Sir F. R. Wingate drove through the Shaata Gate into Suakin city. Both sides of the road for miles, as far as the Moudirieh, were thronged with crowds oheering his Exoellency. Triumphal arches were erected on the route taken by the Sirdar, bearing inscriptions such as "Long live our Governor-General," "Weloome the Sirdar, Sir Wingate Pasha," etc.

The Sirdar and the General Staff lunched at the Moudirieh with Miralai Howard Bey, Mou- dir of Suakin, and about 4.30 p.m. orossed over in the 8udan Government steam launch "Pioneer" to Graham's Point, the party being conducted by Miralai Macauley Bey, Director of Railways. On landing at the pier his Exoel­lency and staff got into a saloon carriage and was shown ovefsall the works at Graham's Point. The Sirdar stopped by Pier No. 1 and watched the British S.S. "Bardistan" discharging railway material into trucks. He then stopped at the workshops and afterwards went as far as the condenser, which is already in working order, Macauley Bey explaining the working of the condenser and ' its machinery. His Excellency was quite pleased with everything lie saw aud congratulated Miralai Macauley Bey on the progress of the port.
The Sirdar then proceeded as far as the new mess-house at Graham's Point, where he will remain as Macauley Bey'B guest during his stay at Suakin.

All the vessels in harbour have dressed ship in honor of the Sirdar's visit, viz., H.M.S. 'Sealark," H.H. Coast Guard cruiser "Abd el- Mouueim," the Sudan Government steamers "Mukhbir" and "Hawk," the Khedivial Mail steamers "Gharbieh" and "Calioubieh," and the British steamers "Clematis" and "Bar distau." The railway works are idle to-day as a general holiday has been given on the oc­casion of the Sirdar's arrival, and the town is quite "en fete."

A reoeption will be held by the Sirdar this afternoon at the Moudirieh, for officers from the rank ofYousbashi and upwards and officials from the 2nd grade upwards. In the evening, his Excellency will visit the town and see the deoorations aud illuminations.

div.head: Assouan Dam.
div.p: Goverment's decision
Sir WM. Wilcocks Interviewed.
(Special to the "Gazette")

Our representative found SirW. Willcocksat an early hour in the new office he has just opened for himself next door to Me. Carton de Wiart, and at once proceeded to ask him his opinion on the recent decree deciding to postpone for three years the raising of the Assouan dam and as a corollary to this measure to stop selling land to reclamation companies.
"i desperately WEAK DECISION.'

What do you think, Sir William, of the decision not to raise the Assouan dam 1—1 think it a desperately weak decision, a regular going back to the old days which preceded the Occupation. There is a large book containing the decisions of committeee which advised sno- oessive Khedives not to raise the water on the Barrage at the head of theDelta.Sir Colin Soott- Moncrieff got me out from India (I was only 31 then) and told me to sit down on the Barrage and advise him. "Mind," he added, "have as your motto—L'audaoe, Candace, toujowt Candace, and if you decide to raise the water and sin accident happens I shall take the responsibility; if you suooeed I shall see that you get oredit for it There is Mr. Macdonald at the Assouan dam; he has seen every stone laid and watched the dam ever since and knows it as no man oan know it I spent two days with him last June and learnt much. He was keen on raising it If I had keen chief I should have taken his opinion against all the engineers and professors of Europe together, 'those two professors with their tittlebat theory thrown in.
SIB HKNJAKTN RAKER'S ADVICE.

But mind, Sir William, you are criticising Sir Benjamin Baker.—No; I am not Sir Benjamin ought not to have been asked to take the responsibility tor raising the dam. Sir Benjamin is no longer as young as when he projected the Forth Bridge, and if you turn to the 12th chapter of Ecclesiastes you will find that one of the unfailing signs of age is "an abiding fear of things that are high." The decision to raise or not raise should have been left to Mr. Macdonald, the resident engineer ; and the decision once taken. Sir Benjamin might have been asked his opinion on the measures proposed, and ^advantage taken of his great experience. Sir Williai) Jarstin might with advantage have imitated Sir Colin Scott-Moncrieff, and taken the advice of the youngest man. Mr. Macdonald is a hard and clear-headed Scotchman from Aberdeen, who would have taken any responsibility.
THE PROTECTIVE WORKS.

Would you tell us what are the protective works they are carrying out below the dam 1— All dams over or through which water flows soour out big holes wherever the rock is weak. Nothing but the aotion of the water can disclose where the weak rook is. When found the rook is repaired, and on the solid repaired bed walls are raised and the water falls into compartments and pockets which break its force. I remember at the Betwa dam, which I* built in India, we did the same thing. There we have floods whiqbT are twice those of the Nile in flood, though of short duration, and where the same holes were dug out and repair­ed in the regular established way. There is no rook in the world with less uniformity than granite,, but water is a splendid searcher and soon lets one know everything.
THE SALE OP LAND.

And what do you think, Sir William, about the decision to stop selling land for reclama­tion t—At first I thought I had stepped into Mesopotamia and was faced with all those difficulties which the Turk lays in the way of progress and advancement, but I recovered my­self on meeting a would-be concessionaire who had stepped into Inferno itself and written up over his office door "Let all who enter here abandon hope." "Ah 1" he said, "the irriga­tion engineers want a soft time of it for three years, and they will all the time be drawing their salaries, while we poor wretches who get no salaries but are paid bythe job will starve." I immediately took hope. I know the Irriga­tion Department better. Did I not belong to it for 25 years 1 I knew they would be sick of their soft time before a couple of months were over.-
UR WXXLLAjrS ALTERNATIVE SCHEME.

Wbat dffyou propose to do t—It was only about ten days ago that'I had the pleasure of meeting Mr. Quellenec, chief engineer of the Suez Canal, He asked me why companies did not store their own summer water on part of the ground they wanted to reolaim ; because he had often thought of the easiness of this being done during his frequent journeys be­tween Port Said and Ismailia, I replied at once that the Government were going4o store it for them at Assouan, and that would be cheaper than storing it for themselves. He contended that companies would be happier if they stored their own water. This has been a very favorite project of mine. In the first edition of my book on Egyptian Irrigation, written in 1888, before the Assouan reservoir was thought of, I was very keen on it and devoted many pages to it In the seoond edition, written in 1898, even after it had been decided to store water at Assouan, I was still keen on it Now that the Government has decided not to raise the Assouan dam for three years, I shall imme­diately mollify my projects for reclamation, and everywhere provide for summer reservoirs on the properties to be reclaimed. This will meet every difficulty. That milliard of oubio metres of water which was to have ben stored at Assouan will be available for storage in the lowlands of the Delta. Snob water will be

not only available for irrigation during thi hard time of summer, but will sweeten the land it lies on. Pumped on to the fields it will be sweet and fresh. Why, even Lake Mareotfr, where water has been evaporated for centuries and is in part evaporated to-day, has begun to become sensibly sweeter since the Mex pumps have worked. Last May I got up sopie speci­mens through the courtesy of tyr. Williams and found that the salt was only 500 per 100,000. In ten years it may be possible to irrigate with the water, if it continues to get sweeter every year. This for a salt lake. With one of our own fresh-water reservoirs, we should have abundance of good water always at hand, and not be dependent on the uncer­tain supplies at the tails of low canals.
RECLAMATION OW LAND.

So, Sir William, you do not take a gloomy view of the situation f—Certainly not If Sir William Garstin will telegraph to Mr. Mac­donald to raise the dam, the water will be stored there. If the Adviser does not care to do that, the water can be stored in the low­lands of the Delta. Indeed, I see more work for engineers than ever. Reclamation of land will become a regular scienoe, and it may he that this system of reclamation of which M. Quellenec is so strong an advocate, will hurry on reclamation more than the water from Assouan could luve done it.

div.head: The Cotton Worm
div.p: Important decree

With reference to the letter from the oom­mittee of the International Chamber of Shipping to the port authorities which we published yesterday, we understand that the latter view with extreme regret the interrup­tion in the hitherto continuously excellent and harmonious relations, existing for more than a quarter of a century, between them­selves and the numerous shipping agencies at Alexandria, of which the above-mentioned Chamber is said to be composed, now caused by a letter full of aspersions and animadver­sions on the administration of the port, emanating from this association. The existence and claim of this body to represent the entire shipping interest of the port only became known to the Administration by its letter to the Earl of Cromer. It does not appear in the annual publication called the "ludicateur Egyptian," which professes to contain a list of all important commercial and maritime associations in Egypt, nor has it ever placed itself in offioial relations with the port in the above oapaoity.

The aspersions and animadversions are made the subjeot of a long "addenda" to a communication of half-a-dozen lines on an entirely different subjeot, and are aooompanied by a request for information as to the circum­stances under which the Rubattino S. S. "Cairo" has been wrecked on the reefs outside the tariff limits of the port.

The public, and therefore the Chamber, having been made aware, through the press that actions at law are pending in the Mixed Courts by the passengers of the "Cairo" against her captain and against the company to which she belongs, the port authorities express them­selves surprised that the Chamber has not recognised the impropriety of the information it asks for being given to the public whilst the matter is yet "aub-judioe." Any information however, (which the Goveramentlawyersconsider it permissible to give, is always at the dispo­sition of the agenoy needing it for its own gonoerns, without any necessity for the iuter- ventioa of the International chamber of Ship­ping, whioh, the port authorities think, should confine itself to matters affecting the general interests of the shipping oommnnity as a whole.
In the present case they think it a matter of great regret that the International Chamber of Shipping should have published in the local 'press the letter-it has addressed to them,

' as it contains an admission of the entire disre­gard by the captain of the "Cairo" of the published hydrographio instructions for enter­ing the Port of Alexandria by the Boghas Pass, which niay have a prejudicial effect in a oourt of law.

div.head: A New Nile Dam
div.p: Possible sites

The seoond appendix to Sir William Garstin's note on . the Assouan Dam consists of the following extracts from the Foreign Office Blue Booh. Egypt (No. 3) 1897, containing his former report as to sites for a dam in the Dongola Province
A comparison of the different Cataracts <u Site* for Id Dam and Reservoir.

> Assouan.—A summary examination of the different cataracts between Assouan and Hatinek strengthens the conviction that the former site is, taking all oonsiderationrinto account, better suited than any of the others fot the construction of a great dam, and at tlw same time for the formation -of a storage reservoir.

The soundness of the rock, the width of the river, and the' distribution of thre summer dis­charge into a number of shallow channels afford immense facilities for the successful completion of such a work. t

Again, south of the 1st oataract, there exists a long reach of river, 345 kilometres fodength, with a slope of 1/12500. The storage oapacity of the channel is, therefore, large in proportion to the height of dam required to hold up the necessary quantity of water.
Lastly, the cultivation in this locality is very scanty, and the hills on either tide closely approach the water's edge, thus forming of themselves natural boundaries to the reservoir.
Other possible sites.—The sites next best suited to Assouan are, taken to order, those of Khaibar, D»lt Hannex snd Wady. Haifa.
As regards the first and third of these, De Gottbeeg's plans give very complete informa­tion regarding their section, depth of water, eto.

Khaibar,—The Khaibar bar is to many respects admirably suited for the construction of a masonry dam. The granite is compact and good, and the depth of water in summer is not greater, in any channel, according to De Gott­berg, than 2 metres. It is true that the year 1857, in which his measurements were taken, was one of exceptionally low summer supply, but even in an average year the depth of water cannot be great.

The width of the river here is about 1,560 metres (very muoh the same as that or Assouan), and the mass of rocks which fortes the bar is some 400 metres wide. The reel crosses this river at an angle of between 60 and 70 degrees.

The flanking works on either side would, for a high darn, be rather costly, as the construc­tion of long masonry retaining walls would be involved. The ground surface at the edge of the channel does not appear to be more than 10 metres above low-water level. The laud rises gradually, and with a moderate slope, away from the river on either bank.

' The great drawback to Khaibar as a possible storage reservoir is that it is practically at the end. of the 3rd cataract, and may be said to forte a portion of the latter. The river in the flistuuw of 63 kilometres between Abou Fatmeh and Khaibar falls between 11 and 12 metres, with a slope of about 1/5000.
This must naturally reduce tfle possible storage area-very largely, and, in order to obtain the required quantity of water, a very high dam would be necessitated.

The strip of land sonth of Khaibar, tooludfog the villages and date palms, would be sub­merged by the reservoir. The cultivated area, although larger in extent than the average of Northern Nubia, is not very great, and, as most of the villages are deserted, the loss to the inhabitants would' not assume very large proportions.' Thie Sudan railway, whioh. at ' KeHdain runs close to the river, would also be put under water, and the alignment would require considerable alteration were a dam tb be constructed here. Khaibar is well worth thinking of as a site for a comparatively small " storage reaiervoir,' supplementary to that of " AssOtiafo should such ever be needed.' "

DAt.—1 DM is1 perhaps another site which might bO hsed for the 'construction of a dam. 'It is practically the head of the second cat*- ract, as between it and the Amara rapid, some 82r Mlbmetres upstream, there is only a differ­ence in level of 3 metres. From thence to 'Khalbar there is a comparatively level stretch of water, 118 kilometres in length, with ah average Slope of 1/13000.

"The river at Dal is of considerable width, and is divided by large and rocky islands into -three principal channels. The main stream at the head of the rapid appears to follow the east bank. The flow of water is so strong, and of such volume, as to give rise to the fear that the depth of water, even at low Nile, must be considerable. Without soundings taken at the above period it is impossible to say to wbat extent the water-level in this channel will fal), bat there are indications to show that the depth mast be much greater than at either Khaibar or Assouan, and it is this fact which renders the site a doubtful one so far as a dam is ooncerned.

Rooks and granite reefs are visible at many points of the stream, but the river is not subdivided into a large number of channels as «t Assouan; and the barrier i» not so well defined as either there or at Khaibar. Flank protective works would be easy of construction pere, as the granite hills closely approach the river on either side, more particularly on the eastern bank.

A dam, supposing that the depth of watef "permitted of its construction, might be bulb here to Almost any height required. The reservoir would* however, submerge the villa gee and plains of Firfcet; Kosheh, and Ginnis, but the cultivation in tense localities is not of L fihy very great importance.
ty would be-the drowning |K (faf Sudan railway, which from Firket to
Kosheh skirts the river at a comparatively lov level. Owing to the natare of the'country, the line oouid not well be removed without verj considerable expense in the shape of blasting or tunnelling.

Hanjtek.—At first sight of HannAf, one is struck with the advantage possessed "by this cataract for the formation of alow dam, which would permanently raise the bed and sur&cf levels of the river, and thus reduce' the heigh to which the water has to be raised in summ' i for irrigation purposes. The formation am! position of the reef seem to lend themselves ft such projects. Situated at the north end o the great Merawi-Abou-Fatmeh reach, in which the chief part of the cultivation of theDongols Province is to be found, it is'evident that i: the summer witter-surface coulfl be permanent ly raised fir a few metres, unfcea-iiirabh advantages to irrigation would' be attained

Unless, however, this dam were pierced wit! sufficient openings to permit of the free passage of the river in flood, such a work would entail an annual rise in the flood levels for a consider­able distance up-stream. This might involve not only the drowning-out of a considerable area of existing cultivation, but also the sub mersiou of important places like Hafir, New Dongola, eto. Without very careful leveling and a study of the dood-levels, extending ovei a series of years, it would be impossible fit estimate the effect of the construction of s solid dam here. The afflux which might be caused in flood by the raised crest wonld have to be very carefully calculated

As a reservoir site Hanufek would be useless A dam of any height oonsistent with the re quirements of water storage would pul a great portion of the provtooe annually under water, and the country upon eithei side of the river being comparatively flat, (he wings on both banks would have to be carried out a great distance.

In other respects this cataract is favorable to the construction of such a work. The granite appears to be sound, the islands are numerous, and, according to Da Gottberg, the deepest water in any channel during the summer of 1867 was not more than 2'60 metres

Wady Halfa.—The Wady Haifa, or Gamai cataract, although in many ways eminently suited as a site for dam, is, owing to its situation, useless as regards storage area. The river valley up-stream of this point rises steadily some 19 metres in a distance of 179 kilometres, which is equivalent to a slope )f 1/4000.

AB8ENCE OF LIMESTONE SoU?H OF ASSOUAN. — In comparing the foregoing Sites with that >f Assouan, it must not be forgotten that south >f the latter place no lime is to be met with, ill required for the work would therefore have x> be imported from a long distanoe, and the sost of masonry would be largely increased.

Conclusion. — In conclusion, the Assouan sataraot is, taking into acoount the conditions rath of a good site for a dam and good storage japacity for a reservoir, greatly superior to all itbers. As regards the first point Khaibar is equally good, if not better, but as regards the second, it is much inferior. Dal, on the co^rary, s as good as Assouan is, so far as the storage s&pacity is concerned, but, owing to (be depth if water, the construction of the dam would >e more difficult and consequently more cxstly. lannek is out of the question as regards a torage reservoir, owing to the levels of tho rauntry lying upstream of it
Wady Haifa being placed at the tail of a ong series of rapids has little or no storage capacity.

Finally, the Irrigation Servioe has always nsisted upon the necessity for the dam being •onstruoted as near as possible to the point at vbich the water will be delivered, in order to edaoe to a minimum the loss resulting from iv&poration, percolation, eto. If the above be, is it mast be, taken into consideration, then 10 comparison is possible between^UsgjMnfahtk he sites lying further south. The former is rat only the best, but the most northerly site; herefore, even if a series of dams be eventually tODstruoted upon the southern rapids, one at he first cataract will always be a necessity.

div.head: An Egyptian Official on the Cotton Worm
div.p: Ghalib Bey's Rejoinder

In our issue of Saturday last we passed some remarks on the subjeot of the recently published pamphlet of Moussa Bey Gbalib,, of> the Ministry of PiiWic ' 'Works, on the cotton worm. Wpisave since received the following protest frdm this excellent official, hut it does' nqt in any way alter onr opinion, and we may state furthermore that we are surprised the Ministry of Public Works allowed the writer to issue the work with his official designation appended, as a false impression is thereby giveii to the public, who will consider that the erroneous statements contained therein are endorsed by the imprimatur of the P.W.D.

Sir,—I beg to request yotf will kindly allow me to reply to yonir review (against my pam­phlet on the cotton-worm) given in your "Gazette" No. 7145 of 11th inst., in which yon say "It is a pity it was ever written and it is so fall of errors that we hope it will not have any wide circulation," and have the present inserted in your newspaper.
The oommon oj^cle of the ootton-wbrm, is lmown lfidre than 35 years ago, and till now no useful method was obtained to prevent the evil effected'Bjf worm to the crop*.

In my pamphlet(quite disapproved by yon) off this sihject fo: which 1 pointed out the measures to be talked For prevention against this calamity, F did not mention that the Worm a PmdUqodtr^ta the de^ I Jmd down that dew and continuation of dampness are a means for the production and appearaneq of wqrms, basing my prospect upon the worm which never apjfoart in crops before the faji of dews. For this reason I stated that the eggs must be in the air, and the moths do not Jay eggs directly on the leaves; and specially traces of this incalculable bevy of moths are scarcely seen before the production and apparition of worms in (Stops.

Moreover, no one of the cycle-inquirers stat­ed that he saw by his own eyes the moth in time it lays its eggs directly on the leaves of crops in fields. All their depositions were based upon the sight of eggs of this insect on the leaves and their hatching and upon the know­ledge of its last phase which is tee moth.

All experiments made for keeping in moths in some particular places in order to know the manner of production did not come to a deci­sive point as to whether moths lay directly eggs on the leaves or in the air whereby descend on the plants. If I have admitted the presence of eggB in the air, that was after, many observations and reasonable arguments I stated in my pamphlet.

Now I can give yon a new proof. The worm of cotton, maize, clover, wheat, being of the same order, where does it, sometimes in some lands of Upper Egypt which remain flooded more than 8 months, appear from, and then eats roots of corn aud olover whereas some years wonld have passed before its last apparition !
Where, were the chrysalides kept in and how did moths and eggs appear, if not transported by wind from other places 1

As to the foot that worms appear in land or on leaves, in some crops without reaching others, that depends on the middle proper for the egg hatching to which oontribnte the early and late sowing, foil and less watering, the dis-! tanoe between the plants, the quantity of ma-1 unre and difference of its org&nio constituents.

However I told in my note that whether be exact the theory of presence of eggs in the air, (according to my opinion) or the moth lays direotly eggs on the leaves, the measures sag-j gested in my pamphlet must at any rate be 1 followed to prevent the evil, which measures do not require any expenses or imply fatigues to the proprietors. Also I have not asked more than try these measures in some fields for preventive against apparition of worms, aim of t ery agriculturist.
Notwithstanding I did not pretend to be a zoologist. I merely set forth my own opinion as irrigation engineer and expert in matter of Egyptian culture. I think there is no evil .i.
I-hope the near future will disoover the truth.
Now I request you will kindly read again my pamphlet in original (vernaoular) and thjC translation so that you may be oonrinoed of the acouraoy of my opinion.—Yoon faithfully,
M. Ghalib.

div.head: British rifle Club (Alex.)

A'list pf subscribers will be printed with the programme for the current season, and distributed fio members in a few' days. The committee wonld, therefore, be obliged if thoee British subjects who are not yet members, and wish to become such, would kindly scud in their names, together with the amount of their Subscription, to the hon. secretary, Mr. H. P. Dickson, 0/0 Messrs. Allen, Alderson & Co., as soon as possible, so that their nafhes may he included in said list
Shooting will now take place on the Musta- pha range every Satnrday, commencing at 2.80 p.m.

In the, financial year of 1905-06 there will be no refitting ol ships carried out abroad except at Gibraltar and Malta, owing to the introduction of, two-year commissions, by which repairs will not be allowed to aocu: mutate.

H.M.S. "Renown"—better known in the fleet as "Jackey Fisher's. Pet"-rhas been selected to conyey T. R. H. the Prince and Princess of Wales from England to Bombay on the occasion of their Indian visit The battle­ship earned this soubriquet owing to the elab­orate embellishments she received when die was Sir John's flagship on the North America and West Indies Station and on the Medi­terranean Station 1897-1901. The figbtfog value of the "Renown" is somewhat impaired by the lapse of years, but she still remains one of the fastest battleships in the fleet. Early in her career she made a remarkable speed record UDder extraordinary circumstances. In returning home from Bermuda she maintained a continuous sea speed of 15 knots per hour, and tiiat with two blades of her propellor knocked off entirely and the third one badly
jmnt, by,ooi|ipg fotW odbtaot /with sunken wreckage. It may be remembered that the "Renown" oonveyed T.R.H. the Dnke and Dpcbesseurfi Connaught to-Bombayi to attend foograat,Oafi)M»tian.at Delhi.

The report of the' Comptroller and Auditor- - General upon1 the Army's ■ store accounts for WOS-d-Wifulldf'foeltmdhely reading. There are 'Specimens of1 waste' aud'dead' kiss to the tax­payer, due to a comprehensive variety of causes, from special muddles at the froijyit South:Africa to the ordinary eccentricities of official lyisinegunethods in-the hume.es UulL-h- .meats. Thei story of the fifty million, rounds of ammunition that-had' to. be rent.,back from South Africa, and most of which appear to be useless even for-field practice*'will .repay fur­ther investigation. But the gem'of the. whole report is the case of-the. jam. As much as 387,704 pounds of it had to be written off at Durban, for the simple reason that more than a million and a quarter of tins which were suppos­ed to contain a pound of jam weTC found by (he contractor wbo purchased them after the war* to contain only twelve ounces each. In some cases the original contracts for the supply of' the jam had expressly mentioned a pound as the quantity. , Naturally, the Auditor- General inquired further of .the. W«»:Office :; had anything been done to.see: that full weight was supplied, and had . the short weight been reported and investigated Simple enough questions ; but they,were asked last April, arid at the end of January, when (his report was finished no answer bad been Returned, In the course of a generation or two the War Office, doubtlc-», will ask for further information as to the fiiiid of jam.

In his annual r port on recruiting General Miles asserts that "influence is sometimes brought even from the pujpit against the work of the recruiter." It is hard to believe that any minister, to whatever denomination he may belong, oouid be guilty ot such scanda­lous misconduct. There have been times, indeed, when any person, clerical or lay, who thns sought to render the King's land forces inefficient wonld have ran risk ot a prosecu­tion for treason. It is nothing short of that crime to dissuade1 young Englishmen from joining the ranks of the country's defenders, and to dp so from'the pnlpit increases the enormity of the offence. I do not speak of patriotism ; those who use their religious influence for such a base purpose mast be necessarily destitute of that virtue. But do they ever reflect that if the Army were to melt away to vanishing point for lack of reoruits, many fields now open to missionary enterprise would be hermetically closed ?

div.head: Under the Mosquito Net
div.p: Two letters that I have received on some of the various subjects relative to the Egyptian people npon which I have written in this column, merit more than passing notice, and I regret that the space at my disposal will not permit ofmy dealing with them at the length I should like to. »

One is from the writer who signed himself "A Resident in Upper Egypt" in a letter to the "Gazette" upon which 1 commented some weeks ago, the other from a well-known resident in the Fayoum. Both these gentlemen write from long experience of the village life of Egypt, and as 1 know that full relianoe can be placed upon their testimony I am exceed­ingly glad to be placed in .possession of their views.

On the subject of "Missions to Mohamedans," which I hope will be the topic of a good many more letters to the "Gazette" than have already appeared,—for it is one of the most important questions of the day,—my attention is called to a sermon by Canon Oldfield, who recently left Egypt alter working here for some years as the representative of the Association for the Furtherance of Christianity in Egypt I have only space for a very few extracts lrom this sermon, which has been published by the S. P. C. K. and shuuld be read by all interested in: the question.

The Canon, after showing that Western melhuds. are quite unsuitable with Eastern people aud must inevitably fail,goes on to say; —"The educated Copt of the future will be the natural means of placing Christianity in a light that Mohamedans can accept," and that "Here is God's instrument, ready to hand."

The Copt "has higher intellectual ability; greater power of mental concentration; a na­tural capacity for assimilating the teaching of the West and clothing it in an Eastern garb; he knows all the unexpected twists and turns of an Eastern mind—here' surely is the instru­ment ready to hand, only requiring to be brightened and sharpened." But, he adds, "a Copt turned into a Western tjpe of Christian ] is often spoiled in the process."..."He is capable l of forming a natural link between the thought of East and West; but if he be wholly Westeri * ised this capacity ceases to exist."
And, adds my correspondent, this Westernis­ing is the sole work of tbe American mission­aries in Egypt, and they do a lot of harm.

I trust that before long he will 6end an­other letter to the "Gazette," for he says he has "determined to write about very important questions? and to tell the English sincerely and i frankly the views of the natives on important i topics," adding, - "I am an Egyptian (Copt) 1 right to the backbone." .

In the days to come it will doubtless be seen that the best way of governing the Bgyp- 1 tian people will be by means of native officials who are in touch with English advisers. As things^re now, the ''native subordinates of an English official ask themselves this question, "What mast we do not to get into trouble with that man T" whereas, if the ofijcial is a : native, the question is, "What can we do to please our chief 1" Willing or un­willing service, which is best, all the world over, and in every conceivable situation in life?

I am again reminded of the urgency of the question of curtailing the facilities enjoyed by the fellaheen for obtaining intoxicating liquors. Here, .again, Ii think it isi the native teacher who is wanted in order that real and permanent good may be dene, and the growing habit of drinking in excess cheeked.
And another question is pressed upon,me, that of the baksheesh demanded from, or-as I would put, it the blackmail levied on the fellaheen by the officials upon whom the small

landowners are so greatly 'dependent for th< lecessary water for their crops. Here are a lev ixtracte from the Fayoum letter: ''Baksheesl ond bribery still exist in the provinces amonj he native district irrigation engineers, anc Jso the young employes of the Moudireh specially in thetinance department.".. ."ifriArrj j-ists in the country as much as during t/u "urkish rule."

1 sincerely hope that this latter statement 3 true to only a very limited extent, otherwiw t would seem that while British rule hai .bolished the extortionate tax-gatherer, it hat ett untouched another evil ot only less mag litude. As 1 remarked a week or two ago, tb< oseate picture drawn by Sir Howard Viuceni vas too highly coloured.

The worst featureconuected with this systen >f demanding baksheesh for all and everj iervice rendered by the native, is the fact that t extends to such work as should be willingl) jerfurmed for the benefit of suffering humanity tut no I 1 am told that unless poor peoph rho meet with accidents resulting in broker uubs, etc., are prepared to pay baksheesh, tht lakim (or native doctor) reports unfavorablj s to their cases to the Markaz.

This is certainly a serious state of things, nd when, in addition, the tact is considereo hat the duties of the hakim frequently extend vera large area of ground and to severaJ lhages, so that his services are often noi •vanabie in cases ot emergency, it appears at f an opportunity for enquiry in this direction undoubtedly presents iteelt, and should only equire to be brought to the notice of th< authorities, in order that the present lament ,ble state ot things may be altered for the letter.

It is a great pleasure to me to commend t< he notice of readers of the "Gazette" the urrent number (dated 16th March) of "Orienl aid Ueeideut." Mission work on which all cat ordialiy agree f orms the principal topic of this reek's issue, viz., the exercise of love instead f cruelty in our treatment of the animal rorid.

I will not anticipate, or spoil the reader's ujoyment,by writing on the two very excellent .nicies that the magazine contains, but contenl ay self with expressing the hupe that they wifi ie widely read, and rivet themselves on the niuds of people who, 1 fear, do not think hall inough about the sufferings wantonly indicted in the animal kingdom by man.

Heartily do I hope that in one way or au ither public opinion may be aroused on thn [uestiou. 1 will indulge in just one quotatior rom one of the magazine articles which accu ately sums up the whole matter: "Cruelty ii tegradiug to the individual and injurious to tin ational life ; it is part of the duty of philan hropy and patriotism also to fight it in everj iossible way."

The S.P.C. A. does excellen t work, especially n such a hospital as that at Boulac, when .nimals found suffering from inhuman treat cent receive care and attention. The societyi ifforts, however, are confined to horses, asses miles, and camels only, aud cases of cruelty u ither animals and birds are apparently allowec o pass unnoticed.

But surely some law exists by which sue! sruelty to birds as that described as taking ilace along the route of the Nile steamers, ii t latter to the '(Gazette" afow days ago, can, u iome measure, be prevented! And yet, grievoni isit is tb read of birds being maimed in ordei o get money from tourists, it should be equal y repulsive to think of pigeods being woundec jy gun shot in matches at which a fashiunabliirowdenjoys the "sport"

One is the cruelty of ignorance and greed o noney combined, the other the refined cruelt; of selfish, well-dressed, and presumably well educated people bent on pleasure. 'Which i the worse of the two 1

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICiare
div.p: The lexandria Water Company contre la Municipal!te etle Gouvtrnement llgyptlen. r

La Compegnie avait assign ii S.E. le Gouver- nenr d'Alexandrie en sa quality de reprAsen- tant de la MnnicipaliW et du Gonvemement, pour entendre declarer nulles et non avenfies oomme faites iHAgalement et aveo excAs ide pouvoire lea operations oumulatives de recen- sement et devaluation ainsi que celle de re­vision de la valeur locative dee propriAtAslde la Cie des Eaux, faites par lea services nluni- cipaux.
Le tribonal de premiere instance ayant doonA satisfaction à la Cqmpsgnie, la Munioi- palitA et le Gouvemement viennent d'inter- joter appel. L'affaire a AtA renvoyAe an rble special. ,

Oomme oe proces interesse le pubho en ge­neral en ce qui conoeme l'impoeition et les actionnaires de la Compagnie en particnlifer, nons publions aujonrd'hni des extraits du juge- ment de premibre instance:—

" Atteudu 31'il reaulte des dispositions du deoret du 13 mars 1884 que la mission unique des conseils de revision conaiste à statner mr des reclamations contre les operations de te- censemeut et devaluation et ten dan tee à »b- tenir une decharge on une reduction defirndAt dans les cas taxativement speoifies aux articles 19 et 20 du dit decret; que leur mission, en d'autres termes, consists à statuer sui tie simples points de fait, à savoir à determine!, en cas de contestation, la valeur locative des im meubles assujettis à l'impflt; que par coatre la contestation du principe mfime de l'inptot sur la propriete batie ne constitue pas ube question d'impdt, a soumettre au conseil da re­vision, mais une question de droit cornmun, à rAsoudre par l'autorite judiciaire; que d&s lors les tribunaux mixtes sont oomputents, en inter- pretation du decret du 13 mars 1884, pour oon- naltre de la demaude d'un etranger en restitn tion de 1'impOt sur la propriete bktie, dont la perception a eu lieu d'une maniere non con- forme au decret;

Qu'en I'espfcce la compagnie demanderesee soutient que les operations d'evalnation et de revision qu'on Ini oppose, out ete faites en violation du decret du 13 mars 1884, sur l'im- pdt de la propriete bfttie, et qu'en outre les reservoirs de Kom-ei-Liok et de Ramleh, ainsi que les fibres, ne sont pas imposables; qu'il s'agit lk de deux questions de droit, puis- que l'une est basee sur uue pretendue illAga- tite dans la procedure suivie par la Munioi- palite dans 1 imposition de ses imineubles et que l'autre comporte l'examen du point à savoir si le deoret organique en question estoni on non applicable sur une categoric toute spA- ciale d'immeubles ; l'examen en d'autres termes d'une pure question de droit;

Mais attendu dans tous les cas que le decret du 13 mars 1884 edicte à la suite d'accords di- plomatiques avec les Puissances Europeennea oonsacre au profit des etrangers une double garantie dans la composition de la Commission devaluation etdu Conseil de revision; or le contribuable etranger requis de payer une taxe dont l'etablissemeut n a pas AtA fait en con- formite des dispositions du susdit decret, se trouve atteiut duns un droit acquis, par un acte adminiatratif, et peut recounr aux tribu- □aux mixtes en reparation du prejudice subit." Qu'il y a done lieu d'A^arter l'exception d'irrecevabilite.

Attendu, au fond, que e'est d'une manure vague et sans precision suffisaute que la de- inauderesse compagnie formule les motifs sur lesquels elle se base pour soutenir la nullite de la procedure suivie par la Municipality dans l'impositiou de ses immeubles, nullite resultant de la non-observation des dispositions pree- crites p&r le decret du 13 mars 1884.

Que ueanmoins ces motifs pourraient se resumer: a) à la cumulation entre Us mains des services municipaux dee operations de receusement et devaluation, b) au defant de publicite des etats de receusement et deva­luation, ce qui anrait empAchA les propriAtaires et autres intAressAs de presenter lours observa­tions et c) à la non production des procAs-ver. baux constatant l'extraction par la voie da sort des nomB oomposant les commissions devalua­tion et de revision, conformement à l'art 4 du subdit deoret.

Attendu d'abord que e'est fort douteux, si la Municipalite, une lois la procedure de l'impo- sition terminAe, est tenne de oonserver à l'Ater- nite les prooAs-verbaux de publicite, affichage et extraction au sort, pour servir à oeux qui auraient un jonr envie de l'attaquer pour inobeervation ; que la production des extraits, certifies conformes, de ses regis- tres, dans lesquels on voit figurer sur le oorps de la feuille le reoensement fait par l'administration et en marge revaluation de chaqe bktisse reoensAe, aveo mention dee noins des membres de oes commissions fait presumer que la designation de oes membres a ete faite confonmAment à la loi, car on ne pourrait an- trement s'expliquer comment toutes oes per­sonnel appartenant k la oategorie des propriA- taires de laville d'Alexandrie, auraient pn accepter leur designation et procAder aux ope­rations 4? revaluation et de la revision s'ils savaient d'avance que leur designation etait entachee d'une nullite radioale et n'etait que l'ceuvre d'un tripotage.
Mais attendu dans tous les cas que la Cie demanderesee ne dAnie pas formeUement la sincerity des registras de la Muaioipalite, ni des extraits produits
Que la Cie demanderesee est loin de pou- voir se plaindre de dAfaut de publicity

Qn'ainsi la pretendue nullitA dels procedure suivie par la Municipality dans l'unposition des immeubles de la demanderesae n'est pas snffi ■anunent Atablie, et la dam&ndu doit par oomA- Quent tire rejttAe quant i oe ohef Drinoioal.

.Mais attendu que e'est à bonne raison cjue la Compagnie demanderesee se plaint de ce que c le conseil de revision, qui n'apour mandat que i de reviser revaluation des bktisses dftment re- t censeeB, a d'office et en outre passant les limi- tes de sa competence, impose des bktisses qui ne figurant pas dans les etats de receusement ] et qui n'ont pas non plus ete evalues par la Commission devaluation (citernes et filtres) ; < Attenda, en effet, que le principe de lafixite i des rAles d'imposit ion pour le tenne et dans les limites etablis par l'art. 7 du decret organique i 13 mars 1884 oonsacre m£me par la jnrispru- i dence de la Cour, rend fixe et immuable pour 8 annees le r61e dont s'agit.... i
Quant aux reservoirs. i

Attendu qne loin de pouvoir gtre compares h des magasins ou entrepots, oh la marchan- dise set simplement placde pour Atre vendue, lee reservoirs ne sqnt, à proprement parlor, ' ifi'un appareil mecanique, quoiqne simple, destine à produire par la force de gravitatiop, i la provision d'eau necesSaire dans les condnites. servant à la distribution de l'eau, e'est-k-dira i un appareil regnlatenr de la pression ; qu'k ce < titre lee reservoirs tombent sons l'application i de la deliberation du conseil des ministres, du i 11 dot. 1886, exemptant 1m machines de tout impel et defendant de les faire entrer dans la : valeur locative des bAtisses

div.head: Egyptian Weights and Measures
div.p: The Committee of the International Cham­ber of Commerce has sent a petition to the Egyptian Government and Lord Cromer on the subject of the extraordinarily ohaotio state of things prevailing in this country in regard to weights tod measures. The Committee asks that some general system should be applied and lays down the following programme for bringing about this muoh needed reform :—

Que le gouvemement Aabliske le dApAt dee prototypes des instruments à se procurer auprAs du Bureau International permanent dee poids et mesures, qu'il r&glemente oe dApAt et la distribution des modules à rApandre dans le pays.
Qu'il Atablisse une rAglemefitation d'abord facultative, puis obligatoire des instruments qui seront seuls lAgalement admis dans le pays.
Qu'il dAsigne limitativement le* instruments autorisAs dans les rapports des administrations pnbliques, du oommerde et de l'industrie.
Qu'il five, en s'inspirantdes boisoins du pays et dee tmauxde la Commission Internationale des poids et mesures, la forme des instruments da dmwe et de mesuragej qu il iadique la

iature de leurs AlAments de constructions j n'il fixe les conditions des instruments desti- -3 a mesurer le degrA des liquides et la densi- i des oorps tels que alcoomAtres, thermomAtreS t densimAtres.
Qu'il donne une sanction pratique aux dis- ositions qu'il Adictera en Atahlissant un ser- ice des poids et mesures destind à appliquer ans le pays entier les lois qui auront 4t4 tablies.
Que le service des poids et mesures soit harg4 de la verification premiere des instrn lents de toute nature avaut tout emploi.
Que ledit Service soit charge de la verifioa- on periodique des instruments en oours d'u- ige.
Qu'il soit charge de la verification des ins- ruments rajustes.
Qu'une surveillance %ctive soit etablie pour eiller à l'exactitude des instruments en ser- ice et pour la representation des fraudes qui araient commises.
Qu'h cet effet des ponvoirs suffisants soient onnes anx tribnnanx pour la repression des ontraventions qui seraient constatees par les gents du Service du contrAle des poids et ins­ures.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING ACTIVITY.
div.p: In view of the existing activity in Egyptian Mining, the Directors of the London and Paris Exchange have retained the services of a competent Mining Engineer, whose reports on the present position of the various properties is of the utmost importance. This Information is at the disposal of Clients. Correspondents contemplating Investment in Egyptian Mining Enterprises would be well advised in communicating with the Exchange before doing so, and thus avoid the loss of capital incurred by the purchase of worthless securities.
The London and Paris Exchange undertake the purchase or sale of all classes of Mining Securities on the London Stock Exchange and Continental Sources.

div.head: Gomme Arabique
div.p: Pendant les deux premiere mois de l'aondi les affaires ont dtd plutdt cal mes et, malgrd lei faibles arrivages, les coure sont restds trks bas, Ainsi, alora que depuis Ddcembre dernier or escomptait des prix dlevds pour cette a mule, ce qui permettait à tout le monde de se rattrapei des pertes subies l'anude derniere, il s'est pro dnit le contraire, et de Fes. 52 à 53 pour IOC kilos cat port frangais, que valait Particle fir Ddcembre 1904, il est tombd dernidrement à 49 frs.

Ceci est dft principalement aux stocks ac cumulus en Europe chez les consommateurs, con fiseurs, droguistes, etc., voire chez les gro: ndgociants importateure. Les consommateurs pourvns poor plusieure mois, ne se ddoidaieni plus à faire de nonveaux achats qu'k des prix ddrisoires et dans le seul but de se order ur stock permanent pour parer à toute dventua Ltd. En outre, les offiies qu'ils recevaient direc tement de l'Egypte contribuaient à les rendre plus mdfiants et plus exigeants.Les ndgociants, k leur tour, ont dtd obligds de nous offrir des prix qui n'ont jamais dtd pratiquds à ce jour.

En second lieu, l'argent manquant au marche d'Omdurman, par suite duf refus formel das banquiere d'avancer de 1'argent aux petits nd- gociants, il n'y a pas eu la concurrence ndees- saire et e'est ainsi que malgrd les arrivages peu importants, Particle est tombd, faute d'ache- teure, à P.T. 51,50 le cantar soudanais de 49 kilos environ. Ce prix s'entend merchandise prise k Omdurman et dquivaudrait, tous frais ajoutd*, à Fes. 49 environ ponr 100 kilos ca( Marseille ou le Hkvre.

Ces prix prdjudiciables ont influence les in­digenes au point de diminuer encore les impor­tations (d'ailleurs, par suite du froid exception- nel, il y a cette anude moins de gomme qu'er 1904), de sorte que ces derniere jours lea am vages à Douem sont tombds à 250-300 cantars par jour, alore que l'annde demidre il en arri vait 1.000 à 1.200 joumellement. Si ceci continue, tout fait prdvoir que d'ici fin Juillet,dpoque à laquelle les arrivages finissent, la rdcolte totale atteindra à peine 110 à 115.000 cantars, contre 235.000 l'annde dernidre, à moins que les prix augmentant, les arrivages n'augmentent dgalement. Ces prdvisions ont produit une certaine activitd à Khartoum et, comme oonsdquence, nous venons d'avoit une hausse de 3 £ piastres par cantar. On ne void pas actuellement au dessous de P.T. 55 le can- tar et peutAtre nous verrons des prix plus dlevds, sinon immddiatement, du moins vers Septembre-Octobre.
Pendant le mois de Janvier il a dtd exports d'Egypte 3:040 colis de 150 à 181 kilos donl 681 colis ponr la France.
Les prix oi-dessus s'entendeut pour la gomme natnrelle en sortes, dure ou mi-friable.
La gomme Kordgfan friable,blanche manque cette qualitd n'arrive pas avant Juin-Juillet.
(Extrait du bulletin de la Chambre de Com meroe Frangaise).

div.head: The Land Bank of Egypt

del'Egyptian Gazette

Je viens de lire dans votre journal, en date de ce jour, une correspondence signde:— ''Un Independent" — et vons prie de publier dans la mfime colonne de votre prochain nu- mdro les quelques lignes qui suivent.

Je suis parmi les courtiers qui ont demands qoe la decision de l'Assamhiee Generals et du Comite de 1'Association des Courtiers en Valeurs an sujet de la "Land Bank of Egypt" soit respectee et j'ai hautemeut proteste lorsqu'on a vouln empdcher les transactions sur cette valeur.
vtyre eorrespondant qui par prudence ou par un sentimint de honte peutAtre assez loua- Ele, a prefer garder l'anonymat, dit que nous etions gagnes à la oause de la Lafid Bank.
Je n'admets pas cette insinuation fnjurieuse etje vous rends civilement et personnellement respdqsable à moins que vous ne preferiez me livrerjle nom de votre eorrespondant anonyme.
Aghlez Monsieur, mes salutations distin- gudes.)C. P. Eodocanachi.

rfits à pnblier toutee les lettres en sens oppose i 'eat le devoir de la Presse d'exposer l'opinion | de tons les interesses à la oonairion, bien en-j tendu, de ne pas attaquer les personnalites. ' M. Rodooanachi nous est jusqu'k cette heure parfiutement inoonnn soit oomme partisan soit - oomme adyersaire de la Land Bans. L'expres-

The total amount therefore payable per Share will be £6: 10/- payable as follows:

Interest at the rate of 7% per annum will be liable to forfeiture if the Instalments are not paid as they fall due as per Article 8 of the Statutes. /
' Applications will be received by the Nation­al Bank of Egypf, Cairo and Alexandria, from 9 a.m. of Monday the 10th day April 1905 to 5 p.m. of Tuesday, the 11th day of April 1905.
Every Shareholder has the right to an allot­ment of two Shares of the present issue for every three Shares held by him at the time of issue.
Any Shares not applied for in virtue of this preferential right ot Shareholders, are offered to the Public for Subscription.

National Bank of Egypt, Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd., Bank ot Egypt Ltd., Credit Lyonnais and Imperial Ottoman Bank, and send to the National Bank of Egypt, before 5 p m. of the 11th day of April 1905 their Application on Form A. with the Bankers' Certificate printed thereon duly completed, together With the amount due on Application.

All other Applications for shares must bo made on Form B. and should also be sent in, accompanied by the sum due on Application, to the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo or Alexandria, before 5 p.m. on Tuesday the 11th day of April 1905.
Application forms can be obtaiued at any of the above Banks.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Mb. R. H. Hoare has now retired from the firm of Hoare and Russell. The business will be carried on by Mr. F.H. Russell, in partnership with Mr. Errol Kerr, C.A., who has been asso- ciated with the firm of Hoare & Russell for some time past as managing clerk. The name of the firm will in future be Russell and Kerr. The business will be carried on at the same offices in Cairo, and at their new offices in Alexandria at 17, Mohamed Aly Square.
