div.head: Egyptian Mines Exploration
div.p: The present position of the company's various holdings

The fourth annual general meeting of the £ shareholders of the Egyptian Mines Explora- tion Company, Limited, was held on the 7th u . rest., at Wiuchosier House, Old Broad-street, g( London, E.C., Mr^fyndale White (the chair- w man) presiding. j
The Secretary (Mr. E. S. G. Malius) read the gj notice convening the meeting and the auditors' u report. . ^

. The Chairman said : You have all had for g( some days copies of the report and balance- v sheet in your possession, and I presume you will wish to take the same as read. That being a your pleasure, I may say our financial position t is so clearly set out in the balance sheet, and | the information contained in Mr. Alford's c report respectingthe work at the different places g where exploration is proceeding is so full, that j very little is left for me to add by way of £ further inlormation. Your directors have every , reason to believe that in the near future the ^ 129,499 shares held by your company in the £ subsidiary companies already formed will show t a very- handsome profit, and you must not 0 forget that your company «is entitled to a con- j siderable interest in any companies hereafter £ formed to take up and work mining leases in the Fatira and Eridia Companies' districts. A • j property in which the developments justify the | early flotation of a mining company is Atallah, j where, you will notice, the assays are of an j exceedingly encouraging nature, and since Mr. 1 Alford's report was written thefollowing assays have come to hand :•— No. < 1 Shaft, vein 15 £ in. wide, 1 oz. 17 dwt. gold per ton ; 170 ft. j level north-east, vein 24 in. wide, 4 oz. 16 dwt. ( gold per ton; 170 ft. level north-east, south ( vein, vein 8 in. wide, 1 oz. 4 dwt. gold per ton; j 170 ft. level south-west, vein 9 in. wide, 2 oz. ( 7 dwt. gold per ton; No. 2 Shaft, 195 ft. level £ north-east, vein 6 dn. wide, 2 oz. 19 dwt. per ton; 195 ft. level south-west, vein 7 in. wide, ( 7 oz. 18 dwt gold per ton. The results also at £ Eridia are very encouraging, and here we have an area of valuable reefs over five miles in ^ extent, which should one day support a great j many companies, in all of which we shall Le , large shareholders. I#S« not outside the bounds j of possibility that-Eridia might one day become the Kalgurli of Egypt. We expect great things j at Semna, where the indications left by the 1 ancients are of great extent and apparent depth, and the vein is wider than we have found it at any other centre so far. Work has been suspended at Fatira, mainly because it would require a considerable expenditure on ; pumping machinery to go further, and the | development there is amply sufficient and encouraging to justify a subsidiary company with sufficient capital to take out a mining lease and develop a good mine, with every prospect of success. The ancient workings here extend over a very large distriot, and the ancient slime heaps in the wady contain thou­sands of tons of slime. Mr. Alford considered, however, that it was much more in all our in­terests to suspend the work here for the pre­sent, and to spend money in proving what we believe to be a very valuable property at Semna.

From Um Rus we are expecting to hear any day the results of the first crushing, which should make your holding in this company a valuable asset. Well, we have secured for you the 129,499 shares set out in the note in the balance-sheet for a total expenditure of £29,873, and, ss I mentioned just now, we are entitled to fur-! (her shares in any company or companies

Making up mining leases, in the Fatira and g iridia Companies' districts, and we have, in e Edition, a vast district south of the Wady ilammama, where we know of seven ancient ( nining centres ; but this district has prac- , ically not yet been touched. By the balance- j iheet you will see that we have in cash and j alls (the latter payable at fixed rates) some ( £9,300, and also £1,000 invested, and you s sill further notice we have 35,000 shares still ( inissued ; so that our financial position is , sound, especially when you consider that the t rork now being carried on on your concession | s being done at the expense of the several sub- r iidiary companies.The boring forcoal which was s mdertaken by the Keneh Company last year j las not so far resulted in fiuding a workable s seam; but I can assure you there are many men, f who ought to know, who believe thatcoal exists, , and we feel confident that if those gentlemen ; are right, if must, from the geological forma-tion of a portion of our concession, exist there. ( Nothing has yet been done with the extensive deposits of phosphate of lime on the western , side of our concession. In March last year we { had further samples of these deposits sent home, and they were analysed iu London by Messrs. Voelcker and Sons, with the result

that one sample gave 71'78 per cent., three others gave 60 per cent., while the average of the seven samples resulted in giving 5875 per cent of tribasic phosphate of lime. We have little doubt that presently these deposits will be worked, and on terms very favorable to ' your interests. As stated in -Mr. Alford's report, there is no difficulty in obtaining nil the. labour we require, and the Arabs are developing into good, practical miners. You will also be pleased to know that at alLlhemines where work is proceeding, there is an ample supply of water from the wells that have been constructed aud reopened on our prospectingarea.

It will also, I am sure, be a great satisfaction to you, as it has been to us, to know that during the past year the staff of Europeans have enjoyed excellent health, aud accidents or sickness among the native employes have been. rare. In conclusion, -I would say no praise could be too great for Mr. Western and our engineers working under him, and 1 am sure you will authorise the directors to add your thanks to theirs to these gentlemen for the loyal and efficient manner in which they have carried out their work during the past year. I now have much pleasure in moving the following resolution : "That the directors' report and balance sheet to December 3 if1904, now submitted to the shareholders, be, and is hereby, adopted.'' (Applause).
Colonel M. Lockwood, M.P., seconded the motion.

Mr. P. E. Beachcroft said : I am sure' we areall satisfied with the very conservative report and accounts which you have presented to us, and, if I may say so, they strike me as being a little too conservative. It is true that in some cases it is impossible to put a value upon the shares which you have received from some of the subsidiary companiesbut in other cases I apprehend that it is not so difficult. Now, With regard to the Um Rus and the Central Egypt Exploration shares, there is, I believe, a market value for them. In a rough estimate I have made of the assets which you hold, I take it that we have at the present moment a known value—without taki*g into consideration any potential value — of close upon £160,000 ; and taking the Fatira and Eridia a3 being only of the value that you have put upon them, namely, £25,000, and taking the Um Rns at the present value of l^V and the Central Egypt at If—you would not.be able to dispose ot 30,000 or 50,000 at that price,
| but it is a fair market value—their present ( market value would be £160,000 of valuable

assets, including the £10,300 yon have already taken credit for. It therefore seems to me that you are too conservative when you put a footnote stating "it is not possible to place a value on the above shares at the present time," and, if you will allow me, I take exception to that. I wonld like to ask you, having taken into' consideration this portion of the assets that you have disposed of by way ( of subsidiary companies, what ypu estimate to be the balance of the property which we hold —what would be, roughly speaking, the area 1 Because, if I am right in my estimate, the remainder of the capital only amounts to something like £50,000 or £55,000. Now, if we have w good value for that £55,000, all I can say is w that we are not shrewd men of business ^ when we allow the shares of this company ^ to be knoclung about for 15s. each, p That is a criticism L make, and, if I am right g in my assumption, I would like to know why this should be. I do not suppose any mining j company in this country possesses a mining ■y expert and engineer of the unsullied reputation j of Mr. Alford. (Applause.) Mr. Alford is a min g who is known to everybody connected with 0 mining, and I had the pleasure of seeing j him with regard to the Um Rus Mine, which I E understand is now not a prospect, but a paya- t ble mine. We are working under the auspices t of a man in the front rank of mining engineers, £ I am a little sorry that, out of all the assets s I you have disposed of, only in one oase, namely, c the Um Rus, have you obtained your conside- £ ration in cash. In the other instances you have j. received shares. You no doubt had your reasons a for that, and, as I have said, you are a very £ conservative body ot men, and it is a pleasure j to be under such a careful administration. You £ have a good cash balance, and with all the c assets and the cash balance I would venture to suggest that perhaps you will hesitate before £ you issue any of those 35,000 unissued shares, B unless there is very good reason for doing so. 5 I think it would be better if our capital remained at £215,000, instead of the authorised t capital of £250,000, unless you are going to make a considerable profit out of it I congra- r tulate you upon the progress you have made, and I only hope that when we meet next year t
we shall hear from your lips a resolution which 1 will be that we shall receive something more c
substantial than promises—I hope a very sub- ( 1 Btantial dividend. s
The Chairman said that he was very much n 1 obliged to Mr. IWchcroit for his criticism,

who always said what he had to say in a j " terse and friendly manner. With regard to the 1 footm te to which Mr. Beachcroft took ex- 3 ception, he might say, without divulging any „ 1 secret, that he was a little bit of his way of >

thinking that those were shares to which t 8 value should be attached, and that therefore c 3 they might have made a better show in the « 1 1 Milan.-e-shcef. His opinion, however, was over c ' ruled by the auditors, who insisted upon j 3 stating it iu the manner in which it appeared 1 r in tl-c accounts, and they were obliged to
satisfy them. The auditors were in the room, j
and they would confirm what he had stated i 3 with_regard to the footsote to which Mr. , 1 Beachcroft had alluded. He would ask Mr. ,
Skinner to reply to the question with regard , ~ to the company's remaining interests. Mr. ,
Skinner had been all through their concessions, ( Q and he could therefore give them better in- | e formation on that important question than he ]
himself could. i
y Mr. C. Weeding Skinner: As some of you

are aware, when our last annual meeting took I ® place, I was in Egypt. I went out there with ' ' Mr. Alford, and I went over all the concessions | r that yofl hold. I can assure you that, after ] ® what I saw there, I was quite surprised at the 1
extent and the^normous number of old work- 0 ings and the vasthxss of them. Of course, the
few places that we have been developing to a 1 8 condition to be leased and taken up by mining
companies are really a very small bit of the ■
whole of our concession. On the north of the concession we have several properties which
y look like turning out very variable mines, and
1 on the other side, in the south part of the concession—the Keneh-Kosseir Road—there are
t seven or eight large ancient workings, which we have seen. They have not been touched,
and, if we only have the money, and if the
shareholders, after seeing and hearing what they have heard to-day, are prepared to come

(l in and subscribe for the balance of the capital, n I have no doubt that they could make very ^ favorable terms with the people who have the options on those shares. If you would do that, .you would put us in a position to expend . money on this other part of the property which we have not yet touched, and that 0 would make the time shorter when you would ' t receive large profits. At the present time we have Um Rus, which is undoubtedly a very i valuable property. I weut down 450 ft. there, and I saw the first shot put in to get into the '
10 level at 450 ft. Since I was there, they hhye gone down a lot further; they have made
re- their shaft a permanent on6, and, as the chair- rt man has told you, we are expecting any day, s, and every day, to receive information announca ing the first crushing taking place there.

e When I was there the place was more or less le a wilderness, with only two wooden houses of inhabited by the Europeans ; but now, judging es from the photographs, and from the informa- w, tion I have received, it is quite a little town, al The machinery that has been put up there is a of the very latest description, and we expect
very great things from there. There was a I very large amount of ore at grass when I was

a out there, which, from a very large sample, a- showed over 1 oz. to the ton. I can assure un you that, in my opinion, you have a very lia valuable concession there, and that yon will ut derive very large profits, if you have the he money to go on and develop it. he Mr. Beachcroft: Mr. 8kinner's remarks are >le very interesting ; but they have not answered re, my qu4|tion as to the area of the property, rot Mr. Skinner : With regard to Mr. Beach- lit oroft'a question, if you ask me to give the

tact proportion of the property unworked 1 mid not do it; hut I can only say what wt ave touched and developed at file presenl loment is only a fraction of the whole thing f you take the south side of the Keneh iosseir road, we have as much of our property here as we have on the north side. We havi one nothing down there, except atUm Rus Ve know of mines there at a place callec >ebach, and another Zeidun, Dagabatch ligdid, and Abu Dabad. There are also twi ither large workings at a place called#- E| Kat

did not see these places myself. I went vet; learly to Debach, south of Um Rus ; but al hat country we have not had the money 0 he time to prospect. I mean to say that w lave concentrated the money we have had t pend on these two particular places, and, n loubt, during the next few months we sha tave another mine at Atallah, which we sha! «in a position to taka a lease of and wor 18 a mine. I do not think I can tell you an] hing nearer than that vrifh regard to th >roportion of our property remaining on on tands; but, certainly we have not disposed c nore than a fourth of our property.
Mr.' Beachcroft: If I remember right w iave some 10,000 square miles, or thereabout ,nd may I ask if we have disposed of onl 1,500 square miles, or one quarter ?
Mr.-Skinner: I should say that we ha\ lot disposed of that.
Mr. Beachcroft: That means that we hat low three-quarters of our property in hand.

Mr. Skinner : We have disposed of it t he development companies—the one to tb lorth of the Keneh-Kosseir road has bee liapoeed of to the Central Egypt Exploratio Company, and the part untouched you ma ay is more than one-half below that—th ;outh of the road.
Mr. Beachcroft: Still, we have at least 5 >er cent, of our original holdings iu hand.
Mr. Skinner: Undoubtedly.

Mr. Beachcroft: I did not ask the questio ibout the water supply; but 1 think it is rery material one which ithiuk you willbeabl o answer satisfactorily. There have been som sriticisms made to the effect that at Fowahki ind on the Atallah Mine we have not sufl iieut water to carry on operations. I believ rou have got sufficient water: but I shoul ike to hear your remarks on this subject.

Mr. Skinner : With regard to the water, tb particular place Mr. Beachcroft meutione s Fowakhir. There is a well there always fu red always running, aud it is in fact one of tb wells of the desert, and we have opened ai ither well there, and there is any amount 1 water to be had at that particular place. I ma »y yon will find partridges and all sorts i birds and animals that come iu from differei parts of the desert because of the water to l found there. It is the most watered part of tl lerert. At all the ch^ier places where we ha\ been working we have opened up ancient wel which had been filled up by the Arabs in timi gone by simply to keep Europeans and othi people out of the desert, because you canm live there without water. The Arabs do ever thing >to keep the place to themselves, ar therefore filled up the wells. We have take stones out of these wells weighingsomehundrei weights. We have put down *a lot of wel of our own, and in one out of every thn where we have gone for water, we have four it. We have in every fttie of our mines plenl of water, both for drinking and other purpose

A Shareholder said the prospectus stati that they had in the Fatira property 1,(X square miles, in the Eridia property !,0( square miles, and in Central Egypt a litt over 1,000 square miles, which left 7,0 miles unexplored, and probably Mr. Beac croft would remember that in the Eridia at Fatira this company was- entitled to on third of everything ; so that only thre sevenths of the property was disposed c and they would get one-third of whatev was found.
Mr. Beachcroft stated that he had ma the remarks, he had because the public large did not know what they had got. I sould not understand why their shares sto their present depreciated value, whi
the Nile Valley Company's shares were standing at a good premium.

The Chairman remarked that he was quite of Mr. Beachcroft's opinion that it was not for the directors to concern themselves about the prices of shares. With regard to water he would like to direct their attention t( the remarks of Mr. Alford, who said that some of these places would have to be worker under one comprehensive scheme.
The resolution was carried unanimously. Mr. Skinner proposed the re-election 0 Mr. Tyndale White and Mr. C. J. Alford, thi 1 retiring directors. "N

This was seconded by Sir Henry Bunbury 1 Bart., and carried unanimomly. i Messrs. Paunell and Co., having been re 1 elected auditors, Mr. Walter White propose! 1 a vote of thanks to the chairman and direc 1 tors, which was carried unanimously, and 1 the proceedings terminated.

In most cases the Mikado's Government has neither affirmed nor denied the loss of ships reported almost weekly during the blockade of Port Arthur, and silence has proved golden in that the Russian succours wandering aimlessly off the East African Coast have not the slight-est notion of the strength of Admiral Togo's fleet. They may have to face five battleships, they may have to face three. The strength of the Japanese destroyer and submarine flotillas is equally unknown. Now and again stories come of fleets 20 strong seen cruising 100 miles E. of Hongkong or of a host of torpedo craft patrolling Formosan waters, but nothing definite and precise.

And if the Japanese secrecy in regard to their naval operations has been successful it has been more successful on land, where, what with Chinamen and correspondents, the chnces of leakage of important news are infinitely greater. But Japan has succeeded up to the great fight at Mukden in keeping concealed the whereabouts of some of her principal units. At Liao-Yang the Guard, 2nd and 12th divi-sions under Kuroki, the 5th and 10th under Nodzu, and the 3rd, 4th and 6th under Oku, with several reserve brigades, formed the Ja-panese army. The 1st was known to have been left at Port Arthur ; where were the rest? In the autumn it became known that the 9th and 11th were at Port Arthur, and early in 1905 it transpired that the 8th had played a promi-nent part at Heikontai. Then there was the 7th; it was only a few days ago that the "Times" correspondent informed the world that this force, destined to conquer Saghalien (said some) or hold Korea, according to others, had actually arrived in November in time to storm the 203-Metre Hill. As for the indepen-dent reserve brigades, no one seems sure of their exact position, nor of the nature of the army of occupation in Korea

And then in the height of the battle of Mukden three territorial divisions under General Kawamura, who, as all the world believed, was landing in N. Korea and pre=paring to assail Vladivostock, appear on General Linievitch and for all the Russian leaders. For this successful calculated secrecy means that you have a whole people before you that is not only patriotic - most people can feel and talk for their country - but has the power of understanding what the pro-secution of a successful war demands. Other nations have scarificed lives in war with the same iron patriotism, others have trained their hearts and wills to accept war, not as a horror and an abomination, nor as a field for theatricals, but as a necessary if highly disagreeable incident in international relations; but none have sacrificed their comfort so far as to refrain from writing or talking copious-ly in war-time, to the great comfort of them-selves and their enemy's Intelligence Depart-ment.
